awd_titl_txt: Novel Polymer Adsorbents for Selective Peptide and Small Protein Separations from Blood
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: 1604170, Guzman
Novel Adsorbents for Selective Peptide and Small Protein Separations from Blood 

Small biomolecules or biomarkers from human blood or other biological fluids such as urine are usually found in trace amounts. Their identification and purification is in general hindered by the high concentration of human albumin and other proteins found in blood and biological fluids. The effective recovery and identification of these biomolecules from complex biological mixtures has been until now a considerable challenge. The methods developed in this research will allow the effective isolation of bioactive peptides, hormones, and biomarkers that can be used in biomedical areas. This research will enable medical applications that isolate and remove toxins from biological fluids and then identify biomarkers for early cancer detection. In this research, selective adsorbents with polymers that do not allow the adsorption of large proteins will be synthesized. The adsorbents will be modified with chemical groups that will permit only the selective adsorption, from complex mixtures of targeted bioactive peptides, hormones and biomarkers that are found only at low concentrations. The technology will be tested in samples from biological fluids such as blood, urine and saliva. Studies will be conducted to obtain higher purification rates for targeted biomolecules. This will translate into lower operation costs in the development and discovery of new biomarkers and in the detoxification and cleaning of human blood. This project will be interdisciplinary in nature, the engineering, biology, and chemical knowledge used and gained in this research will be of interest to many disciplines. This program will involve undergraduate and graduate students from different disciplines with interest in chemistry, molecular biology, medicine, material sciences and chemical engineering.

Despite many efforts to develop efficient protein purification techniques, the isolation of peptides and small proteins on a larger than analytical scale remains a significant challenge. There is currently no similar separation product commercially available. The primary objective of this research will be the development and characterization of a chromatographic adsorbent that allows separation of peptides and biomolecules by simultaneous specific adsorption, and size exclusion using polysaccharide matrices modified with permeation control polymers. This will be accomplished by grafting in chromatographic matrices two different heterogeneous ligands, one, a polymer such as polyethylene glycol that permits the permeation of only certain molecular size range compounds, and a second one, an affinity ligand such as a chelating agent or an ion exchange group that preferentially binds target biomolecules of that specific molecular size range that could cross the restricted polymer barrier. This method will eliminate competition for adsorptive sites on the matrix surface, between large and small molecules, thus increasing adsorption rate and capacity and effective separations and purifications of desired biomolecules. To effectively characterize the properties of these new matrices, systematic dual surface synthesis functionalization protocols will be developed using polyethylene glycol of different sizes and densities as the permeating polymer and chelating and ion exchange groups as affinity ligands.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this NSF funded project was to explore the concept of a new biomolecule separation method specifically aimed for the discovery and isolation of biomarkers, such as peptides and small molecular weight proteins, from biological fluids.

The concept is based on a polymer modulated permeation control mechanism, and the ability to incorporate hydrophilic polymers, and chemically bound affinity ligands on size exclusion hydrogels. These hydrogels (AdSEC adsorbents) consist of (1) a size exclusion chromatographic matrix, (2) a surface grafted with a permeating polymer which acts as a restricted access barrier to large biomolecules present in the target biological fluid, and (3) a specific ligand attached to the surface of the gel matrix.

 

The process is described as a grafted hybrid surface with an affinity ligand and a permeating polymer exposed to a mixture of different, small, and large molecular size proteins. Some of these large proteins have affinity for the surface ligand, and similarly, some low molecular size molecules have affinity for the grafted specific chelating sites as well. In this new approach, only the low molecular size molecules can penetrate the steric barrier, and thus, only the small molecules can potentially interact with the affinity ligands grafted on the surface of the gel, in this project, exemplified by immobilized metal ion affinity ligands.

 

The most relevant outcomes resulted from this project include:

Synthesis of a family of novel adsorbents based on hybrid matrices that include,

  • AGArose-IminoDiacetic Acid-PolyEthylene Glycol.
  • AGArose-DiPicolylAmine-PolyEthylene Glycol.
  • AGArose- TriPicolylAmine --PolyEthylene Glycol.
  • AGArose- CarboxyMethylated HIStidine --PolyEthylene Glycol.
  • AGArose- Highly Acetylated-Ethylene DiAmine --PolyEthylene Glycol.

These new hydrogels together with different metal ions such as copper, nickel, cobalt, and zinc, can be used to prepare many specific adsorbents that can help optimize quite specifically the isolation of target molecules, while rejecting the interaction and adsorption of large proteins from biological fluid mixtures.

 

COVID-19 research related outcomes. The development of a specific method for the preparative isolation of angiotensin I and angiotensin II from human serum. These are bioactive peptides that with the arrival of SARS-CoV-2, have been associated with the poor COVID-19 outcomes to pathophysiological denominators as negative prognostic markers, particularly due to the effect of endogenous, angiotensin II toxicity.

The reason is that the outlook of COVID-19 is negatively correlated with the intracellular accumulation of angiotensin II promoted by the viral blockade of its degrading enzyme receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2). Angiotensin II is an oligopeptide of eight amino acids, formed from its precursor, angiotensinogen, by a series of two enzymatic cleavages of the inactive decapeptide angiotensin I. Angiotensin II binds to its specific receptors and exerts its effects in the brain, kidney, adrenal, vascular wall, and the heart. Upregulated angiotensin II causes premature vascular senescence in this scheme, leading to dysfunctional coagulation and immunity.

In this outcome, we developed a method based on the application of two AdSEC matrices, AGA-IDA--PEG and AGA-DPA--PEG, with systematic chelation of copper and nickel to first isolate both angiotensins from human serum, followed by the specific separation of the two angiotensins I and II, which differ only by two amino acids. In this particular outcome, we developed an approach to isolate and remove angiotensin I and II from human serum, in order to mitigate the possible effects of higher than required concentrations of angiotensin II in the circulatory system.

Similar outcomes resulted from the isolation of these two angiotensins from solutions of large proteins, mainly albumin, and from saliva and urine.

 

A general outcome of this research was the effective synthesis of these new type of hybrid adsorbents, where we systematically developed methodologies to control reaction times for attachment of ligands, permeating polymers, and passivation molecules. The synthesis of these novel adsorbents requires a systematic and rigorous analysis of the densities of permeating polymers attached to the gel surfaces, since the permeating properties were observed to be a function of the affinity ligand attached to the binding surface. This was the most important parameter to produce optimal adsorption-permeation chromatographic matrices for effective separation of larger and small molecular weight biomolecules. We created kinetic profiles of the ligands’ attachment to obtain specific metal ion surface capacities. Similarly, this kinetic analysis allowed us to effectively control the permeating polymer attachment and thus, the surface polymer density that can allow the permeation of specific size molecules to penetrate this barrier.

 

The most significant outcome in this research is that we can prepare a large variety of novel adsorbents to practically eliminate all albumin (or large proteins from complex protein mixtures) from adsorbing on these new gels. This is done by modulating the adsorbent and chelated metal ion and to effectively and efficiently separate and isolate small compounds (potential discovery and isolation of biomarkers) from any biological fluid including, blood, saliva, sweat and urine for example.

 


Last Modified: 06/24/2024
Modified by: Roberto Guzman
